message_text:
<paper>
Paper Title: Observer-Based Sliding Mode Control for Networked Fuzzy Singularly Perturbed Systems Under Weighted Try-Once-Discard Protocol
Paper Abstract: In this article, the sliding mode control issue is investigated for a class of discrete-time Takagi–Sugeno fuzzy networked singularly perturbed systems via an observer-based technique. Moreover, to process the measurement output and schedule the transmission sequence for relieving the communication burden, a logarithmic quantizer and a weighted try-once-discard protocol are synthesized, which can further improve the network bandwidth utilization in networked control systems. Based on the fuzzy observer states, a novel fuzzy sliding surface is established by considering the singularly perturbed parameter properly, and we endeavor to synthesize a sliding mode control law such that the reachability of the prescribed sliding surface could be guaranteed. In addition, by virtue of the convex optimization theory and Lyapunov approach, sufficient conditions are developed to guarantee the asymptotic stability of the sliding mode dynamics as well as the error system with an expected <inline-formula xmlns:mml="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML" xmlns:xlink="http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink"><tex-math notation="LaTeX">$H_{\infty }$</tex-math></inline-formula> performance. Finally, a verification example is presented to illustrate the feasibility and effectivity of the proposed method.
</paper>

<paper_classification>
"contribution" = proposes something new (method, technique, dataset, framework, benchmark, etc.)
"survey" = literature review, overview, meta-analysis, position papers (only references existing work)
</paper_classification>

<entity_types>
task      - Problem being solved (image classification, theorem proving, protein folding)
method    - Technique, algorithm, procedure (gradient descent, CRISPR, induction)
data      - Datasets, databases, benchmarks (ImageNet, MNIST, arXiv corpus)
artifact  - Pre-built: trained models, proof libraries (GPT-4, Mathlib, Cas9)
tool      - Software, instruments, platforms (PyTorch, Lean prover, microscope)
concept   - Abstract ideas, theories, frameworks (attention, category theory)
other     - Entities that don't fit above categories
</entity_types>

<relations>
uses     - Anything EXISTING that the paper uses (methods, datasets, tools, concepts, tasks)
proposes - Anything NEW/NOVEL that the paper creates or introduces

VALIDATION REQUIREMENTS:
- ALL papers MUST have at least 1 "uses" (papers always build on existing work)
- CONTRIBUTION papers MUST have at least 1 "proposes" (they must create something new)
</relations>

<output_json>
{
  "paper_type": "contribution" or "survey",
  "triples": [
    {
      "name": "Wikipedia Article Title",
      "relation": "uses|proposes",
      "entity_type": "task|method|data|artifact|tool|concept|other",
      "wikipedia_url": "https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/...",
      "relevance": "Why this matters (1 sentence)"
    }
  ]
}
</output_json>

<YOUR_TODO_LIST>
FIRST, add ALL of these to your todo list with "TodoWrite" tool:

CRITICAL: Todo content must be copied exactly as is written here, with NO CHANGES. These todos are intentionally detailed so that another LLM could read each one without any external context and understand exactly what it has to do.

1. Read ./triples_output.json. Classify paper as "contribution" or "survey". Edit triples_output.json to set paper_type field.

2. List ALL triples EXPLICITLY mentioned in title/abstract. For each, determine entity_type and relation.

3. For each triple: Use WebSearch tool with allowed_domains=["en.wikipedia.org"] to search "[entity name]" to find the correct Wikipedia article. IMPORTANT: Always include allowed_domains parameter to restrict to English Wikipedia.

4. Edit triples_output.json to add all triples. For each triple:
   - name: Use the Wikipedia article title (e.g., "Gradient descent" not "gradient descent algorithm")
   - relation: how paper relates to entity (uses or proposes)
   - entity_type: one of task, method, data, artifact, tool, concept, other
   - wikipedia_url: The Wikipedia URL from search results (must start with https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/)
   - relevance: 1 sentence explaining why it matters

5. Run validation: python validate_triple_json.py

6. If validation errors: Fix the errors (use WebSearch with allowed_domains=["en.wikipedia.org"] again if needed for incorrect URLs), edit triples_output.json, and rerun validation. MUST REPEAT until validation passes.

<CRITICAL_WEBSEARCH_INSTRUCTIONS>
When using WebSearch, you MUST use the allowed_domains parameter:
WebSearch(query="[your query]", allowed_domains=["en.wikipedia.org"])

This ensures only English Wikipedia results are returned. Do NOT search without allowed_domains.
</CRITICAL_WEBSEARCH_INSTRUCTIONS>
</YOUR_TODO_LIST>

Begin now.

Based on the web search results, here's what I found about Networked Control Systems:

## Definition and Key Characteristics

A networked control system (NCS) is a control system wherein the control loops are closed through a communication network.(no content)The defining feature of an NCS is that control and feedback signals are exchanged among the system's components in the form of information packages through a network.

## Network Types

Networked control systems can use various types of networks, including wireless networks, e.g. Bluetooth, Zigbee, and Z-Wave.(no content)The term wireless networked control system (WNCS) is often used in this connection.

## Key Challenges

The insertion of the communication network in the feedback control loop makes the analysis and design of an NCS complex, since it imposes additional time delays in control loops or possibility of packages loss.

## Research Topics

New control strategies, kinematics of the actuators in the systems, reliability and security of communications, bandwidth allocation, development of data communication protocols, corresponding fault detection and fault tolerant control strategies, real-time information collection and efficient processing of sensors data are some of the relative topics studied in depth.

Networked Control Systems have become increasingly important with the advancement of internet and digital technologies, with applications ranging from building automation to industrial process control.

Web search results for query: "Singular Perturbation Control"

Links: [{"title":"Singular perturbation - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Singular_perturbation"},{"title":"Perturbation theory - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Perturbation_theory"},{"title":"Singular control - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Singular_control"},{"title":"Nonlinear control - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Nonlinear_control_theory"},{"title":"Perturbation theory (quantum mechanics) - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Perturbation_theory_(quantum_mechanics)"},{"title":"Simplified perturbations models - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/SDP4"},{"title":"Controllability Gramian - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Controllability_Gramian"},{"title":"Perturbation problem beyond all orders - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Perturbation_problem_beyond_all_orders"},{"title":"Singular value decomposition - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Singular_value_decomposition"},{"title":"Eigenvalue perturbation - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Eigenvalue_perturbation"}]

Based on the search results, here's information about Singular Perturbation Control:

## Definition

In mathematics, a singular perturbation problem is a problem containing a small parameter that cannot be approximated by setting the parameter value to zero.(no content)Singularly perturbed problems are generally characterized by dynamics operating on multiple scales.

## Application to Control Systems

In control theory, singular perturbation is an important technique for handling systems with multiple time scales. Systems can be divided into two subsystems, one corresponding to faster dynamics and other corresponding to slower dynamics, and then controllers can be designed for each one of them separately.(no content)Through a singular perturbation technique, the two subsystems can be made independent of each other, thereby simplifying the control problem.

## Practical Example

An electrically driven robot manipulator can have slower mechanical dynamics and faster electrical dynamics, thus exhibiting two time scales. Such systems benefit from the singular perturbation approach to simplify controller design.

## In Nonlinear Control Analysis

The singular perturbation method is one of several well-developed techniques for analyzing nonlinear feedback systems.

This technique is particularly useful for systems that naturally exhibit fast and slow dynamics, allowing engineers and mathematicians to decompose complex control problems into more manageable subsystems.

Web search results for query: "Sliding Mode Control"

Links: [{"title":"Sliding mode control - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Sliding_mode_control"},{"title":"Terminal sliding mode - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Terminal_sliding_mode"},{"title":"Integral sliding mode - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Integral_sliding_mode"},{"title":"Talk:Sliding mode control - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Talk:Sliding_mode_control"},{"title":"Predictive control of switching power converters - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Predictive_control_of_switching_power_converters"},{"title":"Runner3 - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Runner3"}]

Based on the search results, here's an overview of Sliding Mode Control:

## What is Sliding Mode Control?

Sliding mode control (SMC) is a nonlinear control method that alters the dynamics of a nonlinear system by applying a discontinuous control signal that forces the system to "slide" along a cross-section of the system's normal behavior.(no content)Sliding mode control is a variable structure control method that switches from one continuous structure to another based on the current position in the state space.

## Key Characteristics

Sliding mode control uses practically infinite gain to force the trajectories of a dynamic system to slide along the restricted sliding mode subspace.(no content)Trajectories from this reduced-order sliding mode have desirable properties (e.g., the system naturally slides along it until it comes to rest at a desired equilibrium).

## Advantages

The main strength of sliding mode control is its robustness. Because the control can be as simple as a switching between two states (e.g., "on"/"off" or "forward"/"reverse"), it need not be precise and will not be sensitive to parameter variations that enter into the control channel. Additionally, because the control law is not a continuous function, the sliding mode can be reached in finite time (i.e., better than asymptotic behavior).

## Challenges

Real implementations of sliding mode control approximate this theoretical behavior with a high-frequency and generally non-deterministic switching control signal that causes the system to "chatter" in a tight neighborhood of the sliding surface. Chattering can be reduced through the use of deadbands or boundary layers around the sliding surface, or other compensatory methods.

## Applications

Sliding mode control has many applications in robotics. In particular, this control algorithm has been used for tracking control of unmanned surface vessels in simulated rough seas with high degree of success.

Based on the search results, here's an overview of Sliding Mode Control:

## What is Sliding Mode Control?

Sliding mode control (SMC) is a nonlinear control method that alters the dynamics of a nonlinear system by applying a discontinuous control signal that forces the system to "slide" along a cross-section of the system's normal behavior.(no content)Sliding mode control is a variable structure control method that switches from one continuous structure to another based on the current position in the state space.

## Key Characteristics

Sliding mode control uses practically infinite gain to force the trajectories of a dynamic system to slide along the restricted sliding mode subspace.(no content)Trajectories from this reduced-order sliding mode have desirable properties (e.g., the system naturally slides along it until it comes to rest at a desired equilibrium).

## Advantages

The main strength of sliding mode control is its robustness. Because the control can be as simple as a switching between two states (e.g., "on"/"off" or "forward"/"reverse"), it need not be precise and will not be sensitive to parameter variations that enter into the control channel. Additionally, because the control law is not a continuous function, the sliding mode can be reached in finite time (i.e., better than asymptotic behavior).

## Challenges

Real implementations of sliding mode control approximate this theoretical behavior with a high-frequency and generally non-deterministic switching control signal that causes the system to "chatter" in a tight neighborhood of the sliding surface. Chattering can be reduced through the use of deadbands or boundary layers around the sliding surface, or other compensatory methods.

## Applications

Sliding mode control has many applications in robotics. In particular, this control algorithm has been used for tracking control of unmanned surface vessels in simulated rough seas with high degree of success.

## Search Results for Lyapunov Stability

Here's what I found about Lyapunov Stability:

### Overview
Lyapunov stability is named after Aleksandr Mikhailovich Lyapunov, a Russian mathematician who defended the thesis The General Problem of Stability of Motion at Kharkov University in 1892.

### Fundamental Concept
Near to a point of equilibrium which is Lyapunov stable the system remains stable under small disturbances. More specifically, Lyapunov stability means that if the system starts in a state in some domain D, then the state will remain in D for all time.

### Types of Stability
Asymptotic stability means that solutions that start close enough not only remain close enough but also eventually converge to the equilibrium.

### Historical Development
A. M. Lyapunov was a pioneer in successful endeavors to develop a global approach to the analysis of the stability of nonlinear dynamical systems by comparison with the widely spread local method of linearizing them about points of equilibrium.(no content)The interest in it suddenly skyrocketed during the Cold War period when the so-called "Second Method of Lyapunov" was found to be applicable to the stability of aerospace guidance systems which typically contain strong nonlinearities.

### Tools and Applications
In the theory of ordinary differential equations (ODEs), Lyapunov functions, named after Aleksandr Lyapunov, are scalar functions that may be used to prove the stability of an equilibrium of an ODE.(no content)Lyapunov stability methods have also been applied to finding equilibrium solutions in traffic assignment problems.

Based on the web search results, here's an overview of Convex Optimization:

## Definition

Convex optimization is a subfield of mathematical optimization that studies the problem of minimizing convex functions over convex sets (or, equivalently, maximizing concave functions over convex sets).

## Key Properties

Every point that is a local minimum is also a global minimum, which is a fundamental advantage of convex optimization problems. Many classes of convex optimization problems admit polynomial-time algorithms, making them computationally tractable.

## Solution Methods

For different types of convex optimization problems, various algorithms are available:

- **Unconstrained problems**: For unconstrained problems with a general convex objective that is twice-differentiable, Newton's method can be used, and gradient descent is another efficient algorithm for unconstrained minimization.

- **Problems with inequality constraints**: A common way to solve them is to reduce them to unconstrained problems by adding a barrier function to the objective function, using what are called interior point methods.

## Applications

Convex optimization can be used to model problems in fields including portfolio optimization, worst-case risk analysis, optimal advertising, statistical regression, model fitting, and electricity generation optimization.

## Software Ecosystem

There is a large software ecosystem for convex optimization, with two main categories: solvers and modeling tools (or interfaces).

Links: [{"title":"H-infinity methods in control theory - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/H-infinity_methods_in_control_theory"},{"title":"H-infinity loop-shaping - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/H-infinity_loop-shaping"},{"title":"Robust control - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Robust_control"},{"title":"Talk:H-infinity methods in control theory - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Talk:H%E2%88%9E"},{"title":"Control theory - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Control_theory"},{"title":"Rosenbrock system matrix - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Rosenbrock_system_matrix"},{"title":"Hamiltonian (control theory) - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Hamiltonian_(control_theory)"},{"title":"L'Hôpital's rule - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/L'H%C3%B4pital's_rule"},{"title":"Infinite H - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Infinite_H"},{"title":"Infinite switch - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Infinite_switch"}]

Based on the search results, here's information about H-infinity Control:

## Overview

H-infinity methods are used in control theory to synthesize controllers to achieve stabilization with guaranteed performance.(no content)A control designer expresses the control problem as a mathematical optimization problem and then finds the controller that solves this optimization.

## Mathematical Basis

H-infinity control comes from the name of the mathematical space over which the optimization takes place: H∞ is the Hardy space of matrix-valued functions that are analytic and bounded in the open right-half of the complex plane defined by Re(s) > 0; the H∞ norm is the supremum singular value of the matrix over that space.(no content)For matrix-valued functions, the norm can be interpreted as a maximum gain in any direction and at any frequency; for SISO systems, this is effectively the maximum magnitude of the frequency response.

## Advantages and Disadvantages

H∞ techniques have the advantage over classical control techniques in that H∞ techniques are readily applicable to problems involving multivariate systems with cross-coupling between channels; disadvantages include the level of mathematical understanding needed to apply them successfully and the need for a reasonably good model of the system to be controlled.

## Applications

Commercial software is available to support H∞ controller synthesis. H-infinity methods form the basis of robust control, which aims to achieve stable and high-performance controllers even when there are uncertainties in the system model.

Based on the search results, here's information about H-infinity Control:

## Overview

H-infinity methods are used in control theory to synthesize controllers to achieve stabilization with guaranteed performance.(no content)A control designer expresses the control problem as a mathematical optimization problem and then finds the controller that solves this optimization.

## Mathematical Basis

H-infinity control comes from the name of the mathematical space over which the optimization takes place: H∞ is the Hardy space of matrix-valued functions that are analytic and bounded in the open right-half of the complex plane defined by Re(s) > 0; the H∞ norm is the supremum singular value of the matrix over that space.(no content)For matrix-valued functions, the norm can be interpreted as a maximum gain in any direction and at any frequency; for SISO systems, this is effectively the maximum magnitude of the frequency response.

## Advantages and Disadvantages

H∞ techniques have the advantage over classical control techniques in that H∞ techniques are readily applicable to problems involving multivariate systems with cross-coupling between channels; disadvantages include the level of mathematical understanding needed to apply them successfully and the need for a reasonably good model of the system to be controlled.

## Applications

Commercial software is available to support H∞ controller synthesis. H-infinity methods form the basis of robust control, which aims to achieve stable and high-performance controllers even when there are uncertainties in the system model.

## Fuzzy Control Systems

Here's comprehensive information about Fuzzy Control Systems from the search results:

### Definition
A fuzzy control system is a control system based on fuzzy logic – a mathematical system that analyzes analog input values in terms of logical variables that take on continuous values between 0 and 1, in contrast to classical or digital logic, which operates on discrete values of either 1 or 0.

### Key Characteristics
Fuzzy logic is used in control systems to allow experts to contribute vague rules such as "if you are close to the destination station and moving fast, increase the train's brake pressure"; these vague rules can then be numerically refined within the system.(no content)Since the fuzzy system output is a consensus of all of the inputs and all of the rules, fuzzy logic systems can be well behaved when input values are not available or are not trustworthy.

### Historical Development
Interest in fuzzy systems was sparked by Seiji Yasunobu and Soji Miyamoto of Hitachi, who in 1985 provided simulations that demonstrated the feasibility of fuzzy control systems for the Sendai Subway. Their ideas were adopted, and fuzzy systems were used to control accelerating, braking, and stopping when the Namboku Line opened in 1987.

### Real-World Applications
Matsushita vacuum cleaners use microcontrollers running fuzzy algorithms to interrogate dust sensors and adjust suction power accordingly.(no content)Hitachi washing machines use fuzzy controllers to load-weight, fabric-mix, and dirt sensors and automatically set the wash cycle for the best use of power, water, and detergent.(no content)Compared to the previous design, the fuzzy controller heats and cools five times faster, reduces power consumption by 24%, increases temperature stability by a factor of two, and uses fewer sensors.

Links: [{"title":"State observer - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/State_observer"},{"title":"Observability - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Observability"},{"title":"Control theory - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Control_theory"},{"title":"Separation principle - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Separation_principle"},{"title":"Observer - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Observer"},{"title":"Ideal observer theory - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Ideal_observer_theory"},{"title":"Ideal observer analysis - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Ideal_observer_analysis"},{"title":"Sliding mode control - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Sliding_mode_control"},{"title":"Talk:State observer - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Talk:State_observer"},{"title":"Ernest Hilgard - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Ernest_Hilgard"}]

Based on the search results, here's information about Observer Control Theory:

## Overview

In control theory, a state observer (also called a state estimator or Luenberger observer) is a system that provides an estimate of the internal state of a given real system, from measurements of the input and output of the real system.

## Purpose and Application

Knowing the system state is necessary to solve many control theory problems; for example, stabilizing a system using state feedback.(no content)In most practical cases, the physical state of the system cannot be determined by direct observation. Instead, indirect effects of the internal state are observed by way of the system outputs.

## Key Concepts

Observability is a measure of how well internal states of a system can be inferred from knowledge of its external outputs.(no content)If a system is observable, it is possible to fully reconstruct the system state from its output measurements using the state observer.

## Integration with Control Design

In control theory, a separation principle states that under some assumptions the problem of designing an optimal feedback controller for a stochastic system can be solved by designing an optimal observer for the state of the system, which feeds into an optimal deterministic controller for the system.

Observer-based control is a fundamental technique in modern control engineering that enables engineers to design controllers for systems where all internal states cannot be directly measured or observed.

Based on the search results, here's what I found about quantization in signal processing:

## Definition

Quantization is the process of mapping input values from a large set (often a continuous set) to output values in a (countable) smaller set, often with a finite number of elements.(no content)Rounding and truncation are typical examples of quantization processes.

## Role in Analog-to-Digital Conversion

An analog-to-digital converter (ADC) can be modeled as two processes: sampling and quantization. Sampling converts a time-varying voltage signal into a discrete-time signal, a sequence of real numbers. Quantization replaces each real number with an approximation from a finite set of discrete values.(no content)Common word lengths are 8-bit (256 levels), 16-bit (65,536 levels) and 24-bit (16.8 million levels).

## Quantization Noise

Quantizing a sequence of numbers produces a sequence of quantization errors which is sometimes modeled as an additive random signal called quantization noise because of its stochastic behavior.(no content)The more levels a quantizer uses, the lower is its quantization noise power.

## Practical Considerations

In order to make the quantization error independent of the input signal, the signal is dithered by adding noise to the signal. This slightly reduces signal-to-noise ratio, but can completely eliminate the distortion.

Quantization is the process of mapping input values from a large set (often a continuous set) to output values in a (countable) smaller set, often with a finite number of elements.(no content)Rounding and truncation are typical examples of quantization processes.

## Role in Analog-to-Digital Conversion

An analog-to-digital converter (ADC) can be modeled as two processes: sampling and quantization. Sampling converts a time-varying voltage signal into a discrete-time signal, a sequence of real numbers. Quantization replaces each real number with an approximation from a finite set of discrete values.(no content)Common word lengths are 8-bit (256 levels), 16-bit (65,536 levels) and 24-bit (16.8 million levels).

## Quantization Noise

Quantizing a sequence of numbers produces a sequence of quantization errors which is sometimes modeled as an additive random signal called quantization noise because of its stochastic behavior.(no content)The more levels a quantizer uses, the lower is its quantization noise power.

## Practical Considerations

In order to make the quantization error independent of the input signal, the signal is dithered by adding noise to the signal. This slightly reduces signal-to-noise ratio, but can completely eliminate the distortion.

- **Sliding mode control** (proposes) - Novel sliding mode approach for networked fuzzy systems

- **Lyapunov stability** (uses) - Asymptotic stability analysis
- **Convex optimization** (uses) - Controller parameter synthesis
- **Quantization (signal processing)** (proposes) - Logarithmic quantizer for bandwidth reduction

### Concepts (3):
- **Networked control system** (uses) - Core problem domain with communication networks
- **Singular perturbation** (uses) - Multi-scale system dynamics handling
- **H-infinity methods in control theory** (uses) - Robust performance specifications
